title: 113_hr3729
content: The Act may be cited as the "Korean Immigration Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the Act. Congress finds that on January 13, 2003, the 100th anniversary of the first wave of Korean immigration to the United States was commemorated by over 100 Korean American communities. In December 1902, 56 men, 21 women, and 25 children arrived in Honolulu, Hawaii, aboard the S.S. Gaelic, marking the beginning of Korean immigration to the US. Since then, approximately 1,000,000 Koreans have immigrated to the United States, with Korean Americans serving in the US Armed Forces in every war. Korean Americans have thrived in the United States through strong family ties, community support, and hard work. They have invigorated various communities and established themselves in professions such as medicine, law, finance, and government. The partnership between the US and Korea has promoted peace, stability, and economic benefits in the Asia Pacific region and beyond. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. According to the United States Code, all coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize Korean immigration and contributions to the United States. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year 2018, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2018. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act include a surcharge: $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the Council for academic scholarships. The Council will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for any coin issuance in a calendar year if already issued. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to comply with the annual issuance limitation under title 31, United States Code. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary will ensure that minting coins under this Act will not cost the government and no funds will be disbursed until all costs are recovered by the Treasury.
